title: R44504
content: Under the OCSLA, the DOI must create five-year programs for oil and gas lease sales in U.S. waters, balancing energy supply and environmental protection. The BOEM leads this process, which involves multiple drafts for public review and comment. The DOI creates five-year programs for oil and gas lease sales in U.S. waters under the OCSLA. The process involves examining all available leasing areas, narrowing down based on economic and environmental analysis, and submitting the final schedule to the President and Congress for approval. The planning process includes a programmatic environmental impact statement (PEIS) as required by NEPA to assess potential environmental impacts from oil and gas exploration and development. The PEIS addresses potential environmental impacts from oil and gas exploration, considers alternatives, and incorporates public comments. The Administration cannot revise a finalized program without restarting the development process, but scheduled sales could potentially be canceled during implementation based on environmental review requirements. The final oil and gas leasing program for 2017-2022 was approved by former Secretary of the Interior Sally Jewell on January 17, 2017. The program includes 11 lease sales on the Outer Continental Shelf (OCS), with 10 in the Gulf of Mexico region and 1 in the Alaska region. Sales in the Atlantic and Pacific regions were not included in the final program. The leasing decisions in BOEM's five-year programs may impact the economy and environment of coastal states and the nation. Congress is typically involved in the planning process, although they do not have approval authority. Members of Congress can influence the program by submitting public comments during formal comment periods. Members of Congress can influence BOEM's five-year offshore oil and gas leasing programs by submitting public comments, evaluating the program in oversight hearings, and introducing legislation to set or alter program terms. The 114th Congress pursued these types of influence with respect to the proposed program for 2017-2022. The report discusses the history and legal framework of the programs, BOEM's development process, previous programs, and the analysis of the program for 2017-2022. Congress plays a role in oversight and legislation related to the program. In 1953, Congress enacted laws addressing jurisdiction and rights off the US coasts, including regulation of oil and gas exploration. The Submerged Lands Act grants coastal states rights up to 3 geographical miles from their coasts, while the OCSLA defines offshore jurisdiction. The OCSLA defines offshore jurisdiction as all submerged lands lying seaward of state coastal waters subject to US jurisdiction. Its primary purpose is to expedite OCS resource development while ensuring environmental protection and meeting national energy goals. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act Amendments of 1978 added new provisions to the OCSLA, including Section 18 mandating the creation of an OCS leasing program to meet national energy needs for a five-year period. These programs, starting in 1980, set schedules for lease auctions, shaping OCS oil and gas exploration and production. The OCSLA has undergone amendments since 1978, with Congress taking actions to alter offshore oil and gas exploration. Acts like the Deep Water Royalty Relief Act of 1995 and the Gulf of Mexico Energy Security Act of 2006 aimed to encourage exploration and production in specific regions. The OCSLA has undergone amendments since 1978, with Congress taking actions to alter offshore oil and gas exploration. Acts like the Deep Water Royalty Relief Act of 1995 and the Gulf of Mexico Energy Security Act of 2006 aimed to encourage exploration and production in specific regions. Congress also placed a moratorium on leasing in certain regions and created a mechanism for revenue sharing with Gulf states and the Land and Water Conservation Fund. Legislative actions removed barriers to leasing in certain OCS regions, shaping subsequent five-year programs. The statutory framework governing BOEM's development of offshore oil and gas leasing programs includes OCSLA, NEPA, and CZMA. Section 18 of the OCSLA mandates the Secretary of the Interior to prepare and maintain an oil and gas leasing program that aligns with national energy needs for a five-year period. The program must consider economic, social, and environmental values of the OCS resources, as well as the potential impact of oil and gas activities. The OCSLA mandates the Secretary of the Interior to consider economic, social, and environmental values of OCS resources and the impact of oil and gas activities. Section 18 directs the scheduling of exploration and production based on various factors, including geographical, geological, and ecological characteristics, environmental considerations, and state laws and policies. The OCSLA mandates the Secretary of the Interior to consider economic, social, and environmental values of OCS resources and the impact of oil and gas activities. Leasing under the five-year program must assure fair market value and include estimates on appropriations and staffing needs. Consultation requirements include input from interested Federal agencies and State Governors. The OCSLA mandates consultation with the Federal Trade Commission and State Governors for proposed programs. The Secretary may also consult with local government officials. The proposed program must be submitted to the governor of each affected state for comments at least 60 days prior to publication in the Federal Register. The Attorney General, in coordination with the Federal Trade Commission, can submit comments on potential effects. The OCSLA requires consultation with the Federal Trade Commission and State Governors for proposed programs. The Secretary must submit the proposed program to Congress and the President at least 60 days before approval, along with an explanation for any rejected recommendations. The Secretary can then approve a final five-year program and revise it at any time with a mandated review process. BOEM carries out the Secretary's responsibilities for the five-year program, including consultation requirements with affected states. BOEM must request input from governors on laws, goals, and policies to consider. Regulations also require publication of the proposed program in the Federal Register. The five-year planning process for the OCSLA involves consultation with the Federal Trade Commission and State Governors, submission to Congress and the President, and publication in the Federal Register. NEPA and CZMA also play a role, requiring detailed environmental impact statements and consideration of alternatives for major federal actions. The agency prepares an environmental impact statement (EIS) for major federal actions without conducting an Environmental Assessment (EA). BOEM assumes the significance of the impact of its five-year programs on the environment and prepares a programmatic EIS (PEIS) concurrently with the program. States under the CZMA are encouraged to enact coastal zone management plans for protection coordination. The CZMA encourages states to enact coastal zone management plans for habitat and resource protection. Approved state programs can receive federal assistance and must address water pollution sources. Federal activities must comply with state programs. The BOEM regulations governing the five-year program require consideration of coastal zone management programs developed by affected states. BOEM requests information on the relationship between state programs and OCS oil and gas activities from governors and the Secretary of Commerce before developing the leasing program. The development of a five-year program by BOEM typically spans two to three years with multiple drafts published for review. The BOEM regulations governing the five-year program require consideration of coastal zone management programs developed by affected states. The development of a five-year program typically spans over two or three years with successive drafts published for review and comment. The program goes through various stages of consultation with state governors, federal agencies, Congress, and the President. Each step involves public comment and environmental review. The five-year program for oil and gas leasing undergoes multiple drafts and reviews, with the initial draft examining all planning areas and public input to develop a schedule of proposed lease sales. Subsequent drafts focus on analyzing and reviewing specific areas listed in the initial schedule, with the possibility of removing proposed sales based on targeted analysis by BOEM. BOEM may remove proposed sales in the final version of the five-year program but will not add new sales without additional environmental reviews. The process begins with a Request for Information in the Federal Register to gather input on energy needs, leasing interests, and environmental concerns. Based on this feedback, they released a draft proposed program (DPP) outlining lease sales for the next five years. The DPP is the first step towards the final program, with BOEM analyzing all OCS planning. The DPP also outlines a schedule for the proposed sales and seeks public input through a scoping process. BOEM received over 1 million comments on the DPP. Since 1980, eight five-year programs have been submitted to Congress and have taken effect after the 60-day review period required by the OCSLA. The 2012-2017 offshore oil and gas leasing program reflected Obama Administration policies post-Deepwater Horizon spill. It included 15 proposed lease sales, with 12 in the Gulf of Mexico and 3 in Alaska (2 later canceled). The 2007-2012 offshore oil and gas leasing program was prepared by the George W. Bush Administration and later resubmitted by the Obama Administration in 2010. It included 21 sales initially, with a revised schedule following a court order in 2009. The 2002-2007 OCS oil and gas leasing plan was submitted to Congress in 2002 under former Secretary of the Interior Gale Norton. It consisted of a schedule of 20 lease sales, 15 of which were held before the program expired in June 2007. The 1992-1997 program for oil and gas leasing was presented to Congress in 1992 under former Secretary of the Interior Manuel Lujan. It included a schedule of 18 sales, with 12 sales held before the program expired in June 1997. The 1997-2002 program was submitted to Congress in 1996 under former Secretary of the Interior Bruce Babbitt, listing 16 sales, with 12 held before the program expired in June 2002. The 1980-1992 oil and gas leasing programs were presented to Congress under different administrations, reflecting their energy policies. The programs included multiple lease sales, with a total of 106 sales held before the last program expired in June 1997. The 1980-1992 oil and gas leasing program, presented to Congress in April 1980 under President Carter's "Energy Message," included 36 proposed sales, with 12 held. This program succeeded the pre-1980 leasing program that spanned almost 30 years. The BOEM released the final offshore oil and gas leasing program for 2017-2022, scheduling 11 lease sales in specific regions of the OCS. The program includes four OCS regions - Gulf of Mexico, Alaska, Atlantic, and Pacific. Lease sales are planned for the Gulf of Mexico and Alaska regions. U.S. offshore crude oil production declined from 31% to 16% of total production between FY2010 and FY2015, while total crude production increased by 73% to 9.4 million barrels per day. Offshore natural gas production also decreased from 9.5% to 4% of total production during the same period. The surge in total U.S. crude oil and natural gas production between FY2010 and FY2015 was driven by increased production of shale gas and shale oil in various onshore formations. This rise in production helped reduce imports, particularly from OPEC countries. The onshore shale oil plays have lower production costs than deepwater plays currently being explored offshore. As of November 1, 2016, there were 917 producing offshore oil and natural gas leases on 4.5 million acres of the OCS, out of a total of 3,431 active leases on 18.3 million offshore acres. The Energy Information Administration (EIA) anticipates lower domestic investment in offshore leases due to soft demand in a low oil and natural gas price environment, potentially impacting future production levels. The Energy Information Administration (EIA) expects decreased domestic investment in oil and gas projects from 2015-2020. The Office of Natural Resources Revenue (ONRR) forecasts lower bonus bid revenues from offshore leasing in the next five fiscal years compared to previous periods. ONRR's estimates for offshore bonus bid revenues have decreased from around $1 billion annually for FY2015-FY2019 to closer to $500 million annually for FY2017-FY2021. The Office of Management and Budget's crude oil price estimates have also decreased from $80-$90 per barrel to $50-$60 per barrel. The FY2015 budget request had estimates of $80-$90 per barrel, which decreased to $50-$60 per barrel in the FY2017 budget request. Low oil prices will impact new investment, but offshore crude oil production in the Gulf of Mexico is expected to reach record levels of 1.91 mbd in 2017 due to new deepwater projects. Energy diversification, including oil and gas production in the Gulf of Mexico, remains a priority according to the 2017-2022 PP. No reserves have been reported along the Atlantic OCS due to no discoveries. Only modest oil reserves are on the Alaska OCS. The U.S. OCS has significant undiscovered oil and gas resources, with the Gulf of Mexico holding the majority. Alaska's resources are mainly in the Chukchi and Beaufort Seas. Some portions of the U.S. OCS were unavailable for leasing consideration in the 2017-2022 program due to presidential withdrawals, congressional moratoriums, or protected status. This included areas in the Eastern and Central Gulf of Mexico affected by the Gulf of Mexico Energy Security Act of 2006. Legislation from the 114th Congress could have impacted the 2017-2022 oil and gas leasing program, including bills like H.R. 1487 and S. 791 which aimed to use an earlier-proposed program for FY2015-FY2020 with 31 lease sales. The bills H.R. 1487 and S. 791 aimed to use an earlier-proposed program for FY2015-FY2020 with 31 lease sales. They directed that 3 lease sales would not be part of the program and required BOEM to conduct a previously proposed sale in the Atlantic region. The bills also mandated BOEM to conduct lease sales every 270 days for areas with commercial interest and approved the program under NEPA without further environmental review. H.R. 1663 would have approved BOEM's DPP for 2017-2022 under NEPA and added lease sales for various regions, including the Chukchi Sea, Beaufort Sea, Bristol Bay, Virginia coast, and other OCS areas with significant oil or gas reserves. The bill also included state revenue-sharing provisions and declared the final program approved under NEPA. It aimed to increase oil production by 3 million barrels per day and 10 billion cubic feet of natural gas. Military protections and revenue sharing with coastal states were included in the bills. The Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources held a hearing on S. 3203, a bill that would have made changes to lease terms for the Alaska region under the OCSLA. Congress has the opportunity to introduce legislation to alter the final version of each five-year program before the Secretary of the Interior can approve it. In the 114th Congress, Representative Doc Hastings introduced H.R. 6082 to replace the current five-year leasing program with a congressionally developed plan including additional lease sales in various regions. The bill passed the House but did not become law. Potential changes to the lease sale schedule for the 2017-2022 program could be considered in the 115th Congress.
